description: From Middle English effeminat, effemynat, from Latin effēminātus, past participle of effēminō, from fēmina (“woman”).

adjectives.description: effeminate (comparative more effeminate, superlative most effeminate)

entries.meaning: (often derogatory, of a man or boy) Exhibiting behaviour or mannerisms considered typical of a female; unmasculine.

examples: The effeminates are males with obviously recognizable traits and mannerisms;  […]

verbs.description: effeminate (third-person singular simple present effeminates, present participle effeminating, simple past and past participle effeminated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic or nonstandard) To make womanly; to unman.
examples: the studie of sciences doth more weaken and effeminate mens minds, than corroborate and adapt them to warre.
